title: Bteghrine
text:
Bteghrine (, also spelled Bteghrin and Btighrin) is a <a href="municipality">municipality</a> in the <a href="Matn%20District">Matn District</a> of the <a href="Mount%20Lebanon%20Governorate">Mount Lebanon Governorate</a> of <a href="Lebanon">Lebanon</a>.
Etymology.
The exact origin of the town name "Bteghrine" is unknown, but possibilities include "Place of Warriors", "Place of Rocks", and "House of the Saddest" - references to a large battle in the area around 1290 that resulted in thousands of deaths. This date corresponds closely with the rise of the <a href="Mamluks">Mamluks</a>, a period which saw numerous battles in the area, including a 1291 rebellion by the <a href="Shi%27a%20Islam%20in%20Lebanon">Shi'a</a> against the new rulers in <a href="Keserwan%20District">Keserwan</a>, the district on the northern border of the <a href="Matn%20District">Matn</a>.
Geography.
Bteghrine is located at . It is bordered by <a href="Mount%20Sannine">Mount Sannine</a> to the east, <a href="Wadi%20el-Jamajem">Wadi el-Jamajem</a> to the north, <a href="Jouar">Jouar</a> to the west, and <a href="Khenchara">Khenchara</a> to the south. The municipality is composed of seven neighborhoods and four outlying areas.
Water.
There are several <a href="Spring%20%28hydrosphere%29">springs</a> used for both <a href="drinking%20water">drinking water</a> and agricultural purposes in Bteghrine. The four primary springs are Zaarour, Manboukh, Mir, and Sparta.
Agriculture.
Bteghrine is situated on a rocky hillside, but supports a thriving, self-sufficient agriculture. Most of the land within the city and the surrounding hills, including the <a href="Meisree">Meisree</a> and <a href="Bsefrine">Bsefrine</a> districts, was fully <a href="Terrace%20%28agriculture%29">terraced</a> to make it more suited for planting. The most common <a href="fruits">fruits</a> and <a href="vegetables">vegetables</a> grown in Bteghrine are: <a href="figs">figs</a>, <a href="grape">grape</a>s, <a href="mulberry">mulberry</a>, <a href="plums">plums</a>, <a href="apple">apple</a>s, <a href="peach">peach</a>es, <a href="persimmon">persimmon</a>, <a href="pomegranate">pomegranate</a>, <a href="Cherry">cherries</a>, <a href="tomato">tomato</a>es, <a href="cucumber">cucumber</a>, <a href="parsley">parsley</a>, <a href="mentha">mint</a>, <a href="wheat">wheat</a>, and <a href="bean">bean</a>s. Small shops in the town process much of the local <a href="produce">produce</a> into <a href="arak%20%28liqueur%29">arak</a>, <a href="molasses">molasses</a>, <a href="wine">wine</a>, and <a href="preserves">preserves</a>.
Economy.
The <a href="http%3A//www.bteghrine.com/SNS.htm">Saliba Nail and Screw factory</a> is the largest single plant in Bteghrine. Additionally, the town has a large number of small shops for blacksmithing, woodworking, car repair and bodywork, leather tailoring, and aluminum manufacturing. The city also enjoys a full set of services including three gas stations, a supermarket, dry cleaner, several specialty and general stores, a large bakery, several bookstores, several clinics, many restaurants, and one hotel. Bteghrine also hosts the central telephone station for the upper Metn region.
Education.
There is one public school in the town named Bteghrine Public School, and one private <a href="Catholic">Catholic</a> school.
Religion.
The vast majority of inhabitants of Bteghrine are <a href="Christianity%20in%20Lebanon">Christians</a>, with roughly 80% <a href="Greek%20Orthodox%20Christianity%20in%20Lebanon">Greek Orthodox</a> and 20% <a href="Melkite%20Christianity%20in%20Lebanon">Melkite Catholic</a>.
